Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service
Funding Account Name: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation
Activity Name: CONSERVING PRIORITY IBAS FOR MIGRATORY B
Activity Description: This project will improve the conservation of Important Bird Areas (IBAS) for migratory shorebird populations in coastal Ecuador at two key shorebird sites: Ecuasal Saltlakes (1300 hectares) and the Canal of Jambel in the Gulf of Guayaquil (aprox. 105,000 hectares). Eighteen species of shorebirds including Red Knot and Marbled Godwit were recorded at these sites. Partners want to understand how long-distance migratory shorebirds use supratidal artificial (shrimp farms) wintering habitats in the Gulf of Guayaquil and seek to create a stronger alliance with the shrimp farms' owners. At Ecuasal Saltlakes there is an ongoing program with three lines of action: ecosystem protection, environmental education and research and monitoring. Ecuasal company has implemented their Surveillance Plan to safeguard the borders of the saltlakes against intruders (artisanal fishermen, bathers, walkers). The company has increased daily patrols to the borders of the salt production plants preventing the presence of fishermen and bathers over weekends and holidays, and this phase will continue monitoring the implementation of a Surveillance Program to reduce shorebird disturbance. Additionally, they will carry out an awareness campaign directed to the local population of Jos Luis Tamayo in Salinas, which has a population of 25,000 people inhabiting right nearby Ecuasal Saltlakes.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service
Funding Account Name: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
Activity Name: The Jama Conservation Corridor: Reforestation and Agroforestry to Reconnect Remnant Semi-deciduous Tropical Forest
Activity Description: The rate of deforestation in Ecuador linked to unsustainable livestock and agricultural practices and illegal timber harvesting is one of the highest in South America; between 1990 and 2010 Ecuador lost 3.3% of its forest cover (978,537 acres). Deforestation and the ensuing land degradation reduces soil productivity leading to increased poverty and food insecurity in rural areas, while also threatening already endangered wildlife. The purpose of this project is to create the Jama Conservation Corridor spanning 69,189 acres in coastal Ecuador by supporting local, interested landowners with activities that will conserve and reforest parts of their land while encouraging sustainable livelihoods. This project will connect the last remnants of semi-deciduous tropical forests in coastal Ecuador through forest restoration, regeneration of abandoned cattle pastures, and groforestry, including silvopasture. Specific activities include: reforesting prioritized areas within the corridor; collecting baseline data for the flora and fauna in reforested areas; providing training to landowners in agroforestry; and facilitating educational outreach activities with local landowners, schools, and decision-makers on sustainable land use practices.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Animal, Plant and Health Inspection Service
Funding Account Name: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses
Activity Name: Surveillance Approaches for Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza
Activity Description: APHIS has supported efforts in South American countries to strengthen biosecurity at livebird markets and to improve surveillance and emergency preparedness for avian influenza, starting with projects conducted in 2014. This project aims at leveraging previous efforts by strengthening the field surveillance to ensure the timely investigation of suspicious cases and the collection of samples for diagnosis. This workshop workshop aims at sharing and harmonizing surveillance approaches for HPAI to ensure the appropriate collection of samples and early detection of HPAI outbreaks.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service
Funding Account Name: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
Activity Name: Towards a Participative Conservation of High-Andean montane forests in northwestern Ecuador
Activity Description: Project activities will reduce the advance of unsustainable agricultural activities through the implementation of sustainable and comprehensive farming activities that will optimize the use of natural resources and promote the conservation of wildlife by identifying and designating natural restoration areas through a new incentive program promoted by the Ministry of Environment that provides a stipend to landowners relative to the extent of their land when they sign a commitment to conserve forested areas for 20 years, including establishing natural and artificial fencing to avoid uncontrolled cattle grazing in forested areas. Funding will cover 1) a meeting to publicize the project activities and identify interested community members who want to participate in the organic agriculture workshop and/or form a new Local Environmental Group in Nono, 2) a 3-day workshop with approximately 40 farmers and cattle ranchers which will include: a) the social, economic, political, and environmental impacts of conventional agriculture; b) principles of organic agriculture; c) methods for recovering degraded soils; d) examples of best practices and successes of organic agriculture; and e) a field practice on making compost and other organic fertilizers, 3) the production of compost and organic fertilizers at the community center for use by any of the contributing community farmers and cattle ranchers, 4) application of organic farminig techniques on at least 5 farms, 5) a GIS analysis of the farms to determine the location of important remnants of high Andean forests and watersheds for biological corridors, and 6) participatory reforestation activities by the existing Local Environmental Group in Pichn.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service
Funding Account Name: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
Activity Name: Conserving East Pacific Green turtles (Chelonia mydas) nesting in the Galapagos Archipelago
Activity Description: The recipient will conduct standardized nesting surveys and threats assessments at Quinta Playa and Las Bachas, as well as conduct a community outreach program and field education programs with local school children. The Darwin Foundation will work closely with Galapagos National Park to develop the capacity of the Park to assume greater responsibility for and expansion of the sea turtle conservation program at the Park.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Funding Account Name: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Activity Name: Reclaiming Civil Society Space in Ecuador
Activity Description: This program aligns with U.S. policy priorities to promote security and the rule of law in the Americas and strengthening civil-society institution to prevent instability, violence, or other crises. Ecuador currently faces a range of challenges beyond its human rights and democratic governance, including economic recession, narco-trafficking, and migration issues on its border with Colombia. This program focuses in particular on recommendations presented to the Government of Ecuador during Ecuador's Universal Periodic Review (UPR) at the United Nations in May 2017. This program engages marginalized populations, such as indigenous communities who submitted recommendations to the UPR, demonstrating the groups' increased capacity. The recommendations offer the Government of Ecuador a guide to how to rejoin the international community by following international norms and standards of protecting citizens' human rights.

Activity Name: Conservation of the Archaeological Collections (4th Century BC to 16th Century AD) at the Archaeological Museum of Jama
Activity Description: The April 2016 Ecuador earthquake severely damaged the town of Jamas archaeological museum and its collection of ancient objects. This project, which includes conservation activities and the compilation of a comprehensive inventory, directly supports the U.S. embassys efforts to assist with post-earthquake recovery and to engage with vulnerable, underserved communities in an economically depressed region of Ecuador.

Activity Name: Special Investigative Unit (SIU 6) Advanced Course, Ecuador
Activity Description: Special Investigative Unit (SIU 6) Advanced Course, Ecuador; This course supplements instruction provided during the SIU Basic Course and provides additional instruction on several aspects of conducting a judicial wire intercept investigation. These include undercover operations, advanced operational planning, tactical entries, confidential Source management, and money laundering

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Drug Enforcement Administration
US Sector Name: Stabilization Operations and Security Sector Reform
Funding Account Name: Drug Enforcement Administration, Salaries and Expenses
Activity Name: Special Investigative Unit (SIU 6) Advanced Course, Ecuador
Activity Description: Special Investigative Unit (SIU 6) Advanced Course, Ecuador; This one-week advanced training course is designed for SIU commanders responsible for supervising units. The course addresses all core topics from a SIU managers perspective which includes the following; management of SIU, DEA oversight of program, operational planning, critical incident response, risk management, officer safety, leadership, ethics and professionalism in law enforcement, confidential source management, the supervision of enforcement operations, as well as the identification of trends associated with narco-terrorism. The course is conducted via a workshop environment and also encourages SIU commanders and DEA management to exchange information in order to make important decisions needed to improve the SIU program

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: not applicable
Implementing Partner Name: Fundacin de Organizaciones Campesinas de Salinas
Funding Account Name: Inter-American Foundation
Activity Name: Transformation and productive support to sheep and alpaca farmers in 3 provinces.
Activity Description: Fundacin de Organizaciones Campesinas de Salinas (FUNORSAL) will consolidate its strategy of working with sheep and alpaca farmers in six indigenous communities and ensure the sustainability of the project's actions. It will help to strengthen the community organizations, improve the local enterprises formed as a result of the project, improve the animal husbandry skills of the farmers, and empower women members. The amendment will also allow FUNORSAL to modernize its wool processing center so it can become more competitive marketing the wool produced by its partner communities.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service
Funding Account Name: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation
Activity Name: PROTECTION OF CRITICAL WINTERING HABITAT FOR NEOTROPICAL MIGRANTS IN ECUADOR
Activity Description: Habitat loss in the neotropics is a key threat to migratory birds, and it is higher in Ecuador than elsewhere in South America. The project addresses this crucial threat by managing 11 protected areas, restoring degraded habitat, and monitoring. The grantee will also implement an outreach program and develop collaboration with national authorities to improve the management of public reserves. ..Species that will benefit include: cerulean warbler, Canada warbler, buff-breasted sandpiper baird's sandpiper, upland sandpiper, olive-sided flycatcher, pectoral sandpiper, Wilson's phalarope western and eastern wood-pewees, Swainson's thrush, swallow-tailed kite , black-and-white warbler, American redstart and Acadian flycatcher...

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service
Implementing Partner Sub-category ID: Universities and Research Institutes - United States
Funding Account Name: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation
Activity Name: COMMUNITY-BASED CONSERVATION OF NEOTROPICAL MIG BIRDS IN ECUADORIAN CHOCO III
Activity Description: The Mache-Chindul Reserve (MCR) is a BirdLife International 'Important Bird Area' that houses at least 27 Neotropical migratory species. However, several thousand people live within its borders, which often results in continued deforestation and habitat degradation. This project will increase habitat protection in the area through the purchase a 140-hectare forest fragment adjacent to the MCR, which is at risk of deforestation. Once acquired, the land will be used as a regional conservation center...Species that will benefit include: bay-breasted warbler, Canada warbler, spotted sandpiper, least sandpiper, semipalmated sandpiper, lesser yellowlegs, Swainson's thrush, western wood-pewee, Acadian flycatcher, Blackburnian warbler, black-and-white warbler, American redstart, scarlet tanager and summer tanager...

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service
Funding Account Name: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation
Activity Name: CONSERVING PRIORITY IBAS FOR AQUATIC MIGRATORY BIRDS IV
Activity Description: This is a follow-up project aimed at improving the conservation of priority areas (IBAS) for migratory shorebird populations in coastal Ecuador. Phase IV includes a new site in the Gulf of Guayaquil, which is considered the most important wintering area for migratory shorebirds in southwest Ecuador. The project will promote the declaration of a new Western Hemisphere Shorebird Reserve Network site and carry out the basic research and monitoring to determine the value of the mudflats for the migratory wintering populations within 110 miles of the study area. The grantee will continue monitoring the implementation of a surveillance program; install informational signs; plant mangroves along a water discharge channel to mitigate water pollution; and build capacities among university students to promote the sustainability of a research and monitoring program at wetlands in coastal Ecuador...Species that will benefit include: snowy plover, Wilson's plover, semipalmated plover, American oystercatcher, lesser yellowlegs, whimbrel, western sandpiper, least sandpiper, short-billed dowitcher and Wilsons phalarope...

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Democracy, Conflict and Humanitarian Assistance
Funding Account Name: Economic Support Fund
Activity Name: Social Services
Activity Description: Assist special populations which may be vulnerable or at-risk on a temporary or chronic basis whose needs are not addressed under emergency humanitarian assistance or other programs. These include groups such as the disabled; orphans, children and at-risk youth; victims of trafficking; victims of gender-based violence; refugees, returnees, ethnic minorities, internally displaced or other socially excluded groups; the elderly; and female heads of household. Depending on circumstances, services may intend to protect groups; mitigate adverse conditions they face, or to remove barriers to help integrate them into society. Components may include measures to increase the capacity of local service and advocacy NGOs and/or professional social workers; to establish public/private service delivery partnerships as well as family and community focused service models; to establish effective referral networks; to develop appropriate service protocols and methods for screening prospective recipients; or to improve public understanding and sensitivity to the needs of the vulnerable. While services provided should not exclude victims of trafficking in persons, programs designed specifically for this group fall under the Peace and Security Objective under the Transnational Crime Area and the Trafficking in Persons and Migrant Smuggling Element.

Activity Name: Ecuadorian Sustainable Tourism Alliance (ESTA)
Activity Description: TheEcuador Sustainable Tourism Alliance worked to spur public-private collaboration and to reach out to new development partners. Furthermore, the Alliance helped to maximize tourism's contribution to natural and cultural conservation by promoting sustainable tourism development standards.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs
Funding Account Name: Department of State, Andean Counterdrug Programs
Activity Name: Andean Counterdrug Initiative: Country Program
Activity Description: U.S. Department of State, International Narcotics Control and Law Enforcement - Andean Counterdrug Initiative. The Andean Counterdrug Programs account funded U.S. assistance to Plan Colombia and follow-on activities from 2000 to 2010. These funds supported the Colombian Army's push into southern Colombia in support of the Colombian National Police, enhanced drug interdiction in Colombia and the region, increased support to the Colombian National Police, provided for economic development in Colombia and the Andean region, and boosted Colombia's local and national government capacity. Beginning in 2010, Andean Counterdrug Programs funds are appropriated in the International Narcotics Control and Law Enforcement account.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
International Purpose Name: Media and free flow of information
Funding Account Name: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Activity Name: Reclaiming Civil Society Space in Ecuador
Activity Description: This program aligns with U.S. policy priorities to promote security and the rule of law in the Americas and strengthening civil-society institution to prevent instability, violence, or other crises. Ecuador currently faces a range of challenges beyond its human rights and democratic governance, including economic recession, narco-trafficking, and migration issues on its border with Colombia. This program focuses in particular on recommendations presented to the Government of Ecuador during Ecuador's Universal Periodic Review (UPR) at the United Nations in May 2017. This program engages marginalized populations, such as indigenous communities who submitted recommendations to the UPR, demonstrating the groups' increased capacity. The recommendations offer the Government of Ecuador a guide to how to rejoin the international community by following international norms and standards of protecting citizens' human rights.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: not applicable
Implementing Partner Name: Movimiento de Economa Social y Solidaria del Ecuador
Funding Account Name: Inter-American Foundation
Activity Name: Intercultural Economic Solidarity Network
Activity Description: Movimiento de Economa Social y Solidaria del Ecuador in Ecuador (MESSE). MESSE will work within northern Ecuador to encourage the application of agroecological practices and develop the fair-trade market for produce by introducing a participatory guarantee systems, a certification process that involves farmers and consumers. The increased income will directly benefit 400 Ecuadorians, 70 percent of whom are women. The nutritional value of diversified crops grown without chemical fertilizers will also reach 4,000 family members and consumers.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: not applicable
Implementing Partner Name: Red de Turismo Comunitario del Austro Pakarian
Funding Account Name: Inter-American Foundation
Activity Name: Strengthening of productive capacities and trade of handicrafts and SME organizations members of Red Pakarian.
Activity Description: Red de Turismo Comunitario del Austro Pakarian in Ecuador (Pakarian). Pakarian will work with 675 artisans from southern Ecuador to develop their production; their skills in business administration, including leadership and negotiation; and outlets for their crafts that operate in Cuenca and online according to the principles of fair trade. The artisans will expand their product line and design repertoire and will form an organization. The resulting increase in income should benefit another 375 Ecuadorians indirectly.

Activity Name: Life for our soils and welfare of families of Biovida
Activity Description: Red de Productoras Agroecolgicas Biovida in Ecuador (Bioveda). Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service
Funding Account Name: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
Activity Name: Conserving East Pacific Green turtles (Chelonia mydas) nesting in the Galapagos Archipelago
Activity Description: The recipient will conduct standardized nesting surveys and threats assessments at Quinta Playa and Las Bachas, as well as conduct a community outreach program and field education programs with local school children. The Darwin Foundation will work closely with Galapagos National Park to develop the capacity of the Park to assume greater responsibility for and expansion of the sea turtle conservation program at the Park.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service
Funding Account Name: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
Activity Name: Reducing Seabird Bycatch to Conserve the Critically Endangered Waved Albatross
Activity Description: this project will significantly reduce fishery-related mortality of the Waved Albatross, through the adoption of an innovative bycatch mitigation fishing technique, called NISURI. In addition significant changes within the fishing community will be made to reduce harmful fishing practices to birds. This information will be shared among colleagues, governing bodies, and international advisory panels to develop long-lasting changes in the fishery practices to reduce bycatch.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Funding Account Name: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Activity Name: Social Services
Activity Description: Assist special populations which may be vulnerable or at-risk on a temporary or chronic basis whose needs are not addressed under emergency humanitarian assistance or other programs. These include groups such as the disabled; orphans, children and at-risk youth; victims of trafficking; victims of gender-based violence; refugees, returnees, ethnic minorities, internally displaced or other socially excluded groups; the elderly; and female heads of household. Depending on circumstances, services may intend to protect groups; mitigate adverse conditions they face, or to remove barriers to help integrate them into society. Components may include measures to increase the capacity of local service and advocacy NGOs and/or professional social workers; to establish public/private service delivery partnerships as well as family and community focused service models; to establish effective referral networks; to develop appropriate service protocols and methods for screening prospective recipients; or to improve public understanding and sensitivity to the needs of the vulnerable. While services provided should not exclude victims of trafficking in persons, programs designed specifically for this group fall under the Peace and Security Objective under the Transnational Crime Area and the Trafficking in Persons and Migrant Smuggling Element.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Funding Account Name: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Activity Name: Natural Resources and Biodiversity
Activity Description: Conserve biodiversity and manage natural resources in ways that maintain their long-term viability and preserve their potential to meet the needs of present and future generations. Activities include combating illegal and corrupt exploitation of natural resources and the control of invasive species. Programs in this element should be integrated with the Agriculture Area under Economic Growth and Conflict Mitigation and Reconciliation Area under the Peace and Security Objective, when applicable and appropriate.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Funding Account Name: Economic Support Fund
Activity Name: Civic Participation
Activity Description: Strengthen the legal, regulatory, institutional, and information environment which protects and enables the growth in associational life and the development of independent and sustainable civil society organizations (CSOs).  Build the capacity of civil society organizations to act as agents for reform and support their participation in democratic decision-making through articulating and representing their members interests, engaging in service delivery, and advocating for issues which become part of the public agenda and are reflected in public policies. Encourage the strengthening of a civic culture which supports democratic institutions and processes, active participation in political and civic life, and the civic virtues of tolerance, pluralism, compromise, trust, and respect for individual rights, including gender equality.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Funding Account Name: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Activity Name: U.S. Forest Service Interagency Agreement
Activity Description: The U.S. Forest Service (USFS) will provide technical assistance to support RDMA's regional Global Climate Change mitigation programs, including the Low Emissions Asian Development (LEAD) and Lowering Emissions in Asia's Forests (LEAF) programs. The USFS will provide targeted technical assistance that supports improved forest carbon assessment methodologies, knowledge-sharing platforms focused on agriculture, forestry, and other land use (AFOLU), natural capital assessment, climate change curriculum development, forest degradation measurement and monitoring, fire management, and sustainable land management. USFS will also facilitate coordination among relevant USG agencies and USAID Missions in the region. Long-term results include strengthened regional capacity of national and international partners in low emission development strategies (LEDS) and sustainable forest management.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Funding Account Name: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Activity Name: Civic Participation
Activity Description: Strengthen the legal, regulatory, institutional, and information environment which protects and enables the growth in associational life and the development of independent and sustainable civil society organizations (CSOs).  Build the capacity of civil society organizations to act as agents for reform and support their participation in democratic decision-making through articulating and representing their members interests, engaging in service delivery, and advocating for issues which become part of the public agenda and are reflected in public policies. Encourage the strengthening of a civic culture which supports democratic institutions and processes, active participation in political and civic life, and the civic virtues of tolerance, pluralism, compromise, trust, and respect for individual rights, including gender equality.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Implementing Partner Sub-category ID: Universities and Research Institutes - United States
Funding Account Name: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Activity Name: AmericasBarometer
Activity Description: Vanderbilt University conducts AmericasBarometer democracy, governance and citizen security surveys in Latin America and Caribbean countries and related country and regional analyses. Country reports and, when requested, oversampling reports can be prepared that compare results from areas with USAID-programs to the rest of the country. The biennial survey includes 40,000 survey across 25 countries in the hemisphere. Vanderbilt is also conducting an impact evaluation of the Agencys crime prevention activities under the Central America Regional Security Initiative (CARSI) in Guatemala, El Salvador and Panama.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service
Funding Account Name: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
Activity Name: Wildlife Without Borders-Western Hemisphere
Activity Description: Project activities will respond to the request for assistance from the Ministry of Environment to reduce the unsustainable hunting of wild species for the wild meat trade by 1) quantifying the impacts of the wild meat trade on wild species along the Maxus road in the Yasun National Park, 2) identifying and understanding the population that generates the demand for wild meat in order to design targeted outreach interventions to alter consumer behaviors, 3) strengthening the capacity of Yasun National Park staff to implement, enforce, and monitor laws protecting wildlife, and 4) building awareness of the wild meat trade and its causes with stakeholders.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service
Funding Account Name: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
Activity Name: Wildlife Without Borders-Western Hemisphere
Activity Description: Project activities will reduce the advance of unsustainable agricultural activities through the implementation of sustainable and comprehensive farming activities that will optimize the use of natural resources and promote the conservation of wildlife by identifying and designating natural restoration areas through a new incentive program promoted by the Ministry of Environment that provides a stipend to landowners relative to the extent of their land when they sign a commitment to conserve forested areas for 20 years, including establishing natural and artificial fencing to avoid uncontrolled cattle grazing in forested areas. Funding will cover 1) a meeting to publicize the project activities and identify interested community members who want to participate in the organic agriculture workshop and/or form a new Local Environmental Group in Nono, 2) a 3-day workshop with approximately 40 farmers and cattle ranchers which will include: a) the social, economic, political, and environmental impacts of conventional agriculture; b) principles of organic agriculture; c) methods for recovering degraded soils; d) examples of best practices and successes of organic agriculture; and e) a field practice on making compost and other organic fertilizers, 3) the production of compost and organic fertilizers at the community center for use by any of the contributing community farmers and cattle ranchers, 4) application of organic farminig techniques on at least 5 farms, 5) a GIS analysis of the farms to determine the location of important remnants of high Andean forests and watersheds for biological corridors, and 6) participatory reforestation activities by the existing Local Environmental Group in Pichn.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs
Funding Account Name: Department of State, Andean Counterdrug Programs
Activity Name: Andean Counterdrug Initiative: Drug Interdiction/Eradication
Activity Description: U.S. Department of State, International Narcotics Control and Law Enforcement - Andean Counterdrug Initiative. The Andean Counterdrug Programs account funded U.S. assistance to Plan Colombia and follow-on activities from 2000 to 2010. These funds supported the Colombian Army's push into southern Colombia in support of the Colombian National Police, enhanced drug interdiction in Colombia and the region, increased support to the Colombian National Police, provided for economic development in Colombia and the Andean region, and boosted Colombia's local and national government capacity. Beginning in 2010, Andean Counterdrug Programs funds are appropriated in the International Narcotics Control and Law Enforcement account.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: U.S. Customs and Border Protection
Implementing Partner Name: U.S. Government - Department of Homeland Security
Funding Account Name: Nonproliferation, Anti-Terrorism, Demining and Related Programs
Activity Name: Inetrnational Border Interdiction Training I (Domestic)
Activity Description: To further the informational exchange with partner nations by reinforcing inspectional techniques and methodologies with counterpart law enforcement agencies in the host nations own operating environment.  Skills previously presented in the US during IBIT by conducting practical exercise at critical port(s) of entry identified by host national.  The goal of this program is to help build an internal train-the-trainer capacity and eventually infuse the curriculum into the formal training regimen of the host nation.

Funding Account Name: Inter-American Foundation
Activity Name: Promote organic cacao production in 22 communities along the Zamora and Nangaritza watersheds in Zamora Chinchipe

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Democracy, Conflict and Humanitarian Assistance
Funding Account Name: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Activity Name: Civic Participation
Activity Description: Strengthen the legal, regulatory, institutional, and information environment which protects and enables the growth in associational life and the development of independent and sustainable civil society organizations (CSOs).  Build the capacity of civil society organizations to act as agents for reform and support their participation in democratic decision-making through articulating and representing their members interests, engaging in service delivery, and advocating for issues which become part of the public agenda and are reflected in public policies. Encourage the strengthening of a civic culture which supports democratic institutions and processes, active participation in political and civic life, and the civic virtues of tolerance, pluralism, compromise, trust, and respect for individual rights, including gender equality.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Democracy, Conflict and Humanitarian Assistance
Funding Account Name: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Activity Name: Civic Participation
Activity Description: Strengthen the legal, regulatory, institutional, and information environment which protects and enables the growth in associational life and the development of independent and sustainable civil society organizations (CSOs).  Build the capacity of civil society organizations to act as agents for reform and support their participation in democratic decision-making through articulating and representing their members interests, engaging in service delivery, and advocating for issues which become part of the public agenda and are reflected in public policies. Encourage the strengthening of a civic culture which supports democratic institutions and processes, active participation in political and civic life, and the civic virtues of tolerance, pluralism, compromise, trust, and respect for individual rights, including gender equality.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Funding Account Name: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Activity Name: PASA with the US Forest Service
Activity Description: This Participating Agency Service Agreement (PASA) with the U.S. Forest Service provides USAID with expert technical staff to develop and manage regional global climate change programs and to assist USG staff in the LAC region in designing and implementing country-specific climate change activities. Benefitting countries include Brazil, Eastern Caribbean regional countries, Colombia, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Guatemala, Haiti, Honduras, Jamaica, Mexico and Peru. This agreement also contributes to USG Global Climate Change goals by providing expert technical assistance to support U.S. funded climate change activities in individual Latin American and Caribbean countries. Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: not applicable
Funding Account Name: Inter-American Foundation
Activity Name: Program: Cuentamelo Todo Ibarra (CTI)
Activity Description: Asociacin Fe y Alegra Ecuador (FyA), $50,000 FyA will develop its program Cuntamelo Todo Ibarra (CTI) targeting 400 at-risk children and adolescents and at least 50 adults in the neighborhood of Alpachaca, Ibarra. Using a mobile school wagon and nearby public spaces, the project team will work with boys and girls between the ages of 5 and 12 and their parents to encourage dialogue, respect and family participation in reading, arts and crafts, team sports, and psycho-social monitoring. The team will also offer young adults between the ages of 13 and 25, music and sports as alternatives to drugs, crime, alcoholism and early pregnancy that permeate their neighborhood. Some parents will be trained to assist with both groups. (EC-429)

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Funding Account Name: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Activity Name: Natural Resources and Biodiversity
Activity Description: Conserve biodiversity and manage natural resources in ways that maintain their long-term viability and preserve their potential to meet the needs of present and future generations. Activities include combating illegal and corrupt exploitation of natural resources and the control of invasive species. Programs in this element should be integrated with the Agriculture Area under Economic Growth and Conflict Mitigation and Reconciliation Area under the Peace and Security Objective, when applicable and appropriate.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Funding Account Name: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Activity Name: Small Project Assistance (SPA) Program with Peace Corps
Activity Description: New Small Project Assistance program award with Peace Corps. The SPA Program enables USAID to have direct development investments and impact in selected priority areas, while supporting U.S. Peace Corps volunteers to engage community members in participatory processes that contribute to capacity building and sustainable development.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: not applicable
Funding Account Name: Inter-American Foundation
Activity Name: Productive Initiatives for Urban Peace
Activity Description: Movimiento Juvenil Paz Urbana (MJPU), $50,000 MJPU will train at least 100 young adults in technical skills, and will place 30 of them in its own enterprises to work in advertising, welding, computer literacy training and providing access to on-line courses in secondary-school subjects. It will help the remaining trainees find jobs or opportunities to acquire additional skills applicable to starting businesses. MJPU will also organize sports and cultural events, including a Peace Festival, that should help neutralize negative stereotypes in favor of an image of young people as agents of positive change. (EC-428)

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Funding Account Name: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Activity Name: Private Sector Productivity
Activity Description: Improve the capacity of businesses to integrate into domestic and international markets through increases in productivity and improvements in corporate governance and the development and application of modern technology and marketing practices. Enhance the capacity of businesses and business associations in terms of their corporate governance capabilities and their application of best practices and technologies to achieve increased production and marketing of products and services. It includes adoption of efficient production processes, improved labor productivity, environmentally-sound management of natural resources and the development of accounting and management systems that can help the company and industry group implement business, labor, product and process standards that enhance business competitiveness. Business capacity development programs may include activities that help men- and women-owned firms and associations respond to these international markets and create regional alliances.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs
Funding Account Name: Department of State, Andean Counterdrug Programs
Activity Name: Andean Counterdrug Initiative: Drug Interdiction/Eradication
Activity Description: U.S. Department of State, International Narcotics Control and Law Enforcement - Andean Counterdrug Initiative. The Andean Counterdrug Programs account funded U.S. assistance to Plan Colombia and follow-on activities from 2000 to 2010. These funds supported the Colombian Army's push into southern Colombia in support of the Colombian National Police, enhanced drug interdiction in Colombia and the region, increased support to the Colombian National Police, provided for economic development in Colombia and the Andean region, and boosted Colombia's local and national government capacity. Beginning in 2010, Andean Counterdrug Programs funds are appropriated in the International Narcotics Control and Law Enforcement account.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Funding Account Name: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Activity Name: U.S. Forest Service Interagency Agreement
Activity Description: The U.S. Forest Service (USFS) will provide technical assistance to support RDMA's regional Global Climate Change mitigation programs, including the Low Emissions Asian Development (LEAD) and Lowering Emissions in Asia's Forests (LEAF) programs. The USFS will provide targeted technical assistance that supports improved forest carbon assessment methodologies, knowledge-sharing platforms focused on agriculture, forestry, and other land use (AFOLU), natural capital assessment, climate change curriculum development, forest degradation measurement and monitoring, fire management, and sustainable land management. USFS will also facilitate coordination among relevant USG agencies and USAID Missions in the region. Long-term results include strengthened regional capacity of national and international partners in low emission development strategies (LEDS) and sustainable forest management.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Democracy, Conflict and Humanitarian Assistance
Funding Account Name: Economic Support Fund
Activity Name: Social Services
Activity Description: Assist special populations which may be vulnerable or at-risk on a temporary or chronic basis whose needs are not addressed under emergency humanitarian assistance or other programs. These include groups such as the disabled; orphans, children and at-risk youth; victims of trafficking; victims of gender-based violence; refugees, returnees, ethnic minorities, internally displaced or other socially excluded groups; the elderly; and female heads of household. Depending on circumstances, services may intend to protect groups; mitigate adverse conditions they face, or to remove barriers to help integrate them into society. Components may include measures to increase the capacity of local service and advocacy NGOs and/or professional social workers; to establish public/private service delivery partnerships as well as family and community focused service models; to establish effective referral networks; to develop appropriate service protocols and methods for screening prospective recipients; or to improve public understanding and sensitivity to the needs of the vulnerable. While services provided should not exclude victims of trafficking in persons, programs designed specifically for this group fall under the Peace and Security Objective under the Transnational Crime Area and the Trafficking in Persons and Migrant Smuggling Element.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Funding Account Name: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Activity Name: PASA with the US Forest Service
Activity Description: This Participating Agency Service Agreement (PASA) with the U.S. Forest Service provides USAID with expert technical staff to develop and manage regional global climate change programs and to assist USG staff in the LAC region in designing and implementing country-specific climate change activities. Benefitting countries include Brazil, Eastern Caribbean regional countries, Colombia, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Guatemala, Haiti, Honduras, Jamaica, Mexico and Peru. This agreement also contributes to USG Global Climate Change goals by providing expert technical assistance to support U.S. funded climate change activities in individual Latin American and Caribbean countries. Activity Description: Special Investigative Unit (SIU) Basic Fundamental Law Enforcement Practices; This is a five week course conducted at the DEA Academy in Quantico, VA and is a requirement for all officers to complete who are assigned to DEA Sensitive Investigative Units (SIU) worldwide. It is based on the DEA Basic Agent training program and covers a wide range of topics in drug law enforcement.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Democracy, Conflict and Humanitarian Assistance
Funding Account Name: Agency for International Development, International Disaster Assistance
Activity Name: Capacity Building, Preparedness, and Planning
Activity Description: Improve the ability of the USG, host countries and other partners to prepare for and mitigate the effects of disasters, including both natural disasters and complex emergencies, taking into account the differences in men and womens freedom of movement and access to information. Activities under this component include any efforts to enhance the capacities of the USG (in Washington and in the field), humanitarian assistance providers, national host-country authorities, and local communities to engage in disaster reduction and response activities. Activities consist of standardized and coordinated assessments, monitoring, information sharing, data and situational analysis, joint planning; enhancement of coping mechanisms, including the capacity to address adaptation to constantly changing situations on the ground including climate variability and climate change.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Funding Account Name: Economic Support Fund
Activity Name: Civic Participation
Activity Description: Strengthen the legal, regulatory, institutional, and information environment which protects and enables the growth in associational life and the development of independent and sustainable civil society organizations (CSOs).  Build the capacity of civil society organizations to act as agents for reform and support their participation in democratic decision-making through articulating and representing their members interests, engaging in service delivery, and advocating for issues which become part of the public agenda and are reflected in public policies. Encourage the strengthening of a civic culture which supports democratic institutions and processes, active participation in political and civic life, and the civic virtues of tolerance, pluralism, compromise, trust, and respect for individual rights, including gender equality.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Funding Account Name: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Activity Name: Natural Resources and Biodiversity
Activity Description: Conserve biodiversity and manage natural resources in ways that maintain their long-term viability and preserve their potential to meet the needs of present and future generations. Activities include combating illegal and corrupt exploitation of natural resources and the control of invasive species. Programs in this element should be integrated with the Agriculture Area under Economic Growth and Conflict Mitigation and Reconciliation Area under the Peace and Security Objective, when applicable and appropriate.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs
Funding Account Name: Department of State, Andean Counterdrug Programs
Activity Name: Andean Counterdrug Initiative: Drug Interdiction/Eradication
Activity Description: U.S. Department of State, International Narcotics Control and Law Enforcement - Andean Counterdrug Initiative. The Andean Counterdrug Programs account funded U.S. assistance to Plan Colombia and follow-on activities from 2000 to 2010. These funds supported the Colombian Army's push into southern Colombia in support of the Colombian National Police, enhanced drug interdiction in Colombia and the region, increased support to the Colombian National Police, provided for economic development in Colombia and the Andean region, and boosted Colombia's local and national government capacity. Beginning in 2010, Andean Counterdrug Programs funds are appropriated in the International Narcotics Control and Law Enforcement account.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Funding Account Name: Agency for International Development, Development Credit Authority
Activity Name: Private Sector Productivity
Activity Description: Improve the capacity of businesses to integrate into domestic and international markets through increases in productivity and improvements in corporate governance and the development and application of modern technology and marketing practices. Enhance the capacity of businesses and business associations in terms of their corporate governance capabilities and their application of best practices and technologies to achieve increased production and marketing of products and services. It includes adoption of efficient production processes, improved labor productivity, environmentally-sound management of natural resources and the development of accounting and management systems that can help the company and industry group implement business, labor, product and process standards that enhance business competitiveness. Business capacity development programs may include activities that help men- and women-owned firms and associations respond to these international markets and create regional alliances.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Funding Account Name: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Activity Name: Social Services
Activity Description: Assist special populations which may be vulnerable or at-risk on a temporary or chronic basis whose needs are not addressed under emergency humanitarian assistance or other programs. These include groups such as the disabled; orphans, children and at-risk youth; victims of trafficking; victims of gender-based violence; refugees, returnees, ethnic minorities, internally displaced or other socially excluded groups; the elderly; and female heads of household. Depending on circumstances, services may intend to protect groups; mitigate adverse conditions they face, or to remove barriers to help integrate them into society. Components may include measures to increase the capacity of local service and advocacy NGOs and/or professional social workers; to establish public/private service delivery partnerships as well as family and community focused service models; to establish effective referral networks; to develop appropriate service protocols and methods for screening prospective recipients; or to improve public understanding and sensitivity to the needs of the vulnerable. While services provided should not exclude victims of trafficking in persons, programs designed specifically for this group fall under the Peace and Security Objective under the Transnational Crime Area and the Trafficking in Persons and Migrant Smuggling Element.

Activity Name: Legislative Function and Processes

Focus on the quality and effectiveness of legislation, including the constitution, codes, laws, and regulations applying to various development sectors. Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Implementing Partner Sub-category ID: Universities and Research Institutes - United States
Funding Account Name: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Activity Name: AmericasBarometer
Activity Description: Vanderbilt University conducts AmericasBarometer democracy, governance and citizen security surveys in Latin America and Caribbean countries and related country and regional analyses. Country reports and, when requested, oversampling reports can be prepared that compare results from areas with USAID-programs to the rest of the country. The biennial survey includes 40,000 survey across 25 countries in the hemisphere. Vanderbilt is also conducting an impact evaluation of the Agencys crime prevention activities under the Central America Regional Security Initiative (CARSI) in Guatemala, El Salvador and Panama.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Population, Refugees, and Migration
Funding Account Name: Department of State, Educational and Cultural Exchange Programs,
Activity Name: For the Fundacion Albergue Santa Rita to improve the capacity and physical infrastructure of its refugee shelter in Quito
Activity Description: The Bureau of Population, Refugees and Migration's Ambassadors' Fund provides Ambassadors at U.S. embassies with the means to respond quickly to critical, low-cost gaps in refugee assistance and protection.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Funding Account Name: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Activity Name: Social Services
Activity Description: Assist special populations which may be vulnerable or at-risk on a temporary or chronic basis whose needs are not addressed under emergency humanitarian assistance or other programs. These include groups such as the disabled; orphans, children and at-risk youth; victims of trafficking; victims of gender-based violence; refugees, returnees, ethnic minorities, internally displaced or other socially excluded groups; the elderly; and female heads of household. Depending on circumstances, services may intend to protect groups; mitigate adverse conditions they face, or to remove barriers to help integrate them into society. Components may include measures to increase the capacity of local service and advocacy NGOs and/or professional social workers; to establish public/private service delivery partnerships as well as family and community focused service models; to establish effective referral networks; to develop appropriate service protocols and methods for screening prospective recipients; or to improve public understanding and sensitivity to the needs of the vulnerable. While services provided should not exclude victims of trafficking in persons, programs designed specifically for this group fall under the Peace and Security Objective under the Transnational Crime Area and the Trafficking in Persons and Migrant Smuggling Element.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Funding Account Name: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Activity Name: Enhancing Capacity for Low Emission Development Strategies
Activity Description: Enhancing Capacity for Low Emission Development Strategies (EC-LEDS) is a flagship U.S. government effort that assists partner countries in developing and implementing LEDS. The program, which advances the international goals of theU.S. Climate Action Plan, enhances partner country efforts by providing targeted technical assistance and building a shared global knowledge base on LEDS.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Funding Account Name: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Activity Name: Private Sector Productivity
Activity Description: Improve the capacity of businesses to integrate into domestic and international markets through increases in productivity and improvements in corporate governance and the development and application of modern technology and marketing practices. Enhance the capacity of businesses and business associations in terms of their corporate governance capabilities and their application of best practices and technologies to achieve increased production and marketing of products and services. It includes adoption of efficient production processes, improved labor productivity, environmentally-sound management of natural resources and the development of accounting and management systems that can help the company and industry group implement business, labor, product and process standards that enhance business competitiveness. Business capacity development programs may include activities that help men- and women-owned firms and associations respond to these international markets and create regional alliances.

Activity Description: Develop and conduct needs assessments, baseline studies, targeted evaluations, special studies or other information-gathering efforts specifically for the design, monitoring and evaluation of USG-funded programs. This sub-element may also include developing and disseminating best practices and lessons learned, testing demonstration and/or pilot models, or the preparation of strategic plans and other short-term programming tasks. Note: All such activities that are carried out by partners as an integral part of their monitoring and evaluation efforts for programs funded under other sub-elements should be included within those sub-elements.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Funding Account Name: Economic Support Fund
Activity Name: Civic Participation
Activity Description: Strengthen the legal, regulatory, institutional, and information environment which protects and enables the growth in associational life and the development of independent and sustainable civil society organizations (CSOs).  Build the capacity of civil society organizations to act as agents for reform and support their participation in democratic decision-making through articulating and representing their members interests, engaging in service delivery, and advocating for issues which become part of the public agenda and are reflected in public policies. Encourage the strengthening of a civic culture which supports democratic institutions and processes, active participation in political and civic life, and the civic virtues of tolerance, pluralism, compromise, trust, and respect for individual rights, including gender equality.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs
Funding Account Name: Department of State, Andean Counterdrug Programs
Activity Name: Andean Counterdrug Initiative: Drug Interdiction/Eradication
Activity Description: U.S. Department of State, International Narcotics Control and Law Enforcement - Andean Counterdrug Initiative. The Andean Counterdrug Programs account funded U.S. assistance to Plan Colombia and follow-on activities from 2000 to 2010. These funds supported the Colombian Army's push into southern Colombia in support of the Colombian National Police, enhanced drug interdiction in Colombia and the region, increased support to the Colombian National Police, provided for economic development in Colombia and the Andean region, and boosted Colombia's local and national government capacity. Beginning in 2010, Andean Counterdrug Programs funds are appropriated in the International Narcotics Control and Law Enforcement account.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Democracy, Conflict and Humanitarian Assistance
Funding Account Name: Economic Support Fund
Activity Name: Social Services
Activity Description: Assist special populations which may be vulnerable or at-risk on a temporary or chronic basis whose needs are not addressed under emergency humanitarian assistance or other programs. These include groups such as the disabled; orphans, children and at-risk youth; victims of trafficking; victims of gender-based violence; refugees, returnees, ethnic minorities, internally displaced or other socially excluded groups; the elderly; and female heads of household. Depending on circumstances, services may intend to protect groups; mitigate adverse conditions they face, or to remove barriers to help integrate them into society. Components may include measures to increase the capacity of local service and advocacy NGOs and/or professional social workers; to establish public/private service delivery partnerships as well as family and community focused service models; to establish effective referral networks; to develop appropriate service protocols and methods for screening prospective recipients; or to improve public understanding and sensitivity to the needs of the vulnerable. While services provided should not exclude victims of trafficking in persons, programs designed specifically for this group fall under the Peace and Security Objective under the Transnational Crime Area and the Trafficking in Persons and Migrant Smuggling Element.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Democracy, Conflict and Humanitarian Assistance
Funding Account Name: Agency for International Development, International Disaster Assistance
Activity Name: Capacity Building, Preparedness, and Planning
Activity Description: Improve the ability of the USG, host countries and other partners to prepare for and mitigate the effects of disasters, including both natural disasters and complex emergencies, taking into account the differences in men and womens freedom of movement and access to information. Activities under this component include any efforts to enhance the capacities of the USG (in Washington and in the field), humanitarian assistance providers, national host-country authorities, and local communities to engage in disaster reduction and response activities. Activities consist of standardized and coordinated assessments, monitoring, information sharing, data and situational analysis, joint planning; enhancement of coping mechanisms, including the capacity to address adaptation to constantly changing situations on the ground including climate variability and climate change.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Educational and Cultural Affairs
Funding Account Name: Department of State, Diplomatic and Consular Programs
Activity Name: Restoration of an Historic Conventual Bakery in the Todos Santos Section of Cuenca
Activity Description: To support the restoration of the bakery building of an historic convent complex and the site of the areas first flour mill and wood-fired oven. The entire structure has deteriorated due to age, earthquakes, and fires, leaving major portions of the complex unusable for more than a century. This project involves the restoration of the main kitchen and adjacent rooms and the revival of the buildings original function as a bakery.

Implementing Partner Name: Fundacin Afro-Ecuatoriana de Desarrollo Social Jvenes Progresando
Funding Account Name: Inter-American Foundation
Activity Name: Unification and Strengthening of the Organization and Families in Las Orqudeas, and nearby communities.
Activity Description: FAEDSJP will work in Barrio Las Orquideas and surrounding neighborhoods in Esmeraldas with families of children enrolled in its soccer program. Participants will develop proposals to improve their living conditions. The 300 Afro-Ecuadorians involved will include 200 young people between the ages of seven to 17; another 1,200 residents of nearby communities will benefit indirectly.

Activity Name: I Have a Dream - Strengthening Personal and Social Leadership among women of African Descent in Comunas Rios in the Nothern Zone of Esmeraldas, Ecuador.
Activity Description: AMATIF will work on a plan to promote women's leadership, improve management of community-owned natural resources and agricultural production, assure a more reliable food supply, increase income and otherwise improve the quality of life for more than 400 women in las Comunas Rios Santiago, Cayapas and Onzoles. More than 2,500 other residents will benefit indirectly from this strategic planning process.

Activity Name: Implementation of Two Live Bird Market Seminars for the Prevention of Avian Influenza Virus for Backyards, Small Poultry Producers and Traders
Activity Description: APHIS/IICA sponsored Biosecurity program in Ecuador's whole poultry production chain. Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Animal, Plant and Health Inspection Service
Funding Account Name: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses
Activity Name: Implementation of Two Live Bird Market Seminars for the Prevention of Avian Influenza Virus for Backyards, small Poultry Producers and traders in Ecuador
Activity Description: APHIS and IICA sponsored a Biosecurity Program targeted Ecuador's whole poultry production chain. The event showed the risk of introduction of AI and others to small poultry production facilities and is expected to improve Ecuador's poultry chain. From 01/04/2010 to 03/19/2010.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Funding Account Name: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Activity Name: Social Services
Activity Description: Assist special populations which may be vulnerable or at-risk on a temporary or chronic basis whose needs are not addressed under emergency humanitarian assistance or other programs. These include groups such as the disabled; orphans, children and at-risk youth; victims of trafficking; victims of gender-based violence; refugees, returnees, ethnic minorities, internally displaced or other socially excluded groups; the elderly; and female heads of household. Depending on circumstances, services may intend to protect groups; mitigate adverse conditions they face, or to remove barriers to help integrate them into society. Components may include measures to increase the capacity of local service and advocacy NGOs and/or professional social workers; to establish public/private service delivery partnerships as well as family and community focused service models; to establish effective referral networks; to develop appropriate service protocols and methods for screening prospective recipients; or to improve public understanding and sensitivity to the needs of the vulnerable. While services provided should not exclude victims of trafficking in persons, programs designed specifically for this group fall under the Peace and Security Objective under the Transnational Crime Area and the Trafficking in Persons and Migrant Smuggling Element.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Funding Account Name: Economic Support Fund
Activity Name: Private Sector Productivity
Activity Description: Improve the capacity of businesses to integrate into domestic and international markets through increases in productivity and improvements in corporate governance and the development and application of modern technology and marketing practices. Enhance the capacity of businesses and business associations in terms of their corporate governance capabilities and their application of best practices and technologies to achieve increased production and marketing of products and services. It includes adoption of efficient production processes, improved labor productivity, environmentally-sound management of natural resources and the development of accounting and management systems that can help the company and industry group implement business, labor, product and process standards that enhance business competitiveness. Business capacity development programs may include activities that help men- and women-owned firms and associations respond to these international markets and create regional alliances.

Funding Account Name: Economic Support Fund
Activity Name: Program Support (Civil Society)
Activity Description: Establish and/or develop a broadly functioning independent media sector, which is a crucial factor in democratic governance. Building this sector is accomplished through such activities as providing infrastructure and equipment to ensure access to information, shaping the media legal and regulatory environment, boosting professional capacity of the media sector, promoting sustainability through encouraging media-related business development and sound financial/management practices, and supporting advocacy and networking among media sector organizations.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Global Health
International Sector Name: Maternal and Child Health, Family Planning
Funding Account Name: Department of State, Global Health Programs
Activity Name: Child Survival and Health Grants Program (CSHGP) - Center for Human Services
Activity Description: The CSHGP facilitates a dynamic partnership between USAID and private and voluntary organizations (PVOs)/NGOs. Through the CSHGP, USAID leverages the development entrepreneurship and know how of PVOs/NGOs and their local partners for innovative and effective community-oriented programming that sustainably improves maternal, newborn and child health (MNCH) outcomes, strengthens local and community health systems, and contributes to reductions in morbidity and mortality. PVOs/NGOs, with their local partners (national and local MOH, local NGOs/CBOs, communities), implement in a range of settings, from remote communities in a single district to multiple districts or a province. Projects address critical health needs of vulnerable populationsand work strategically with a systems approach at the household, community,health facility, and policy levels and strengthens linkages as relevant.

Activity Description: FODIMUF will work with eight women's organizations to improve income, leadership and organizational skills in eight cantones, or territorial subdivisions, in the province of Esmeraldas. Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs
Funding Account Name: Department of State, Andean Counterdrug Programs
Activity Name: Andean Counterdrug Initiative: Drug Interdiction/Eradication
Activity Description: U.S. Department of State, International Narcotics Control and Law Enforcement - Andean Counterdrug Initiative. The Andean Counterdrug Programs account funded U.S. assistance to Plan Colombia and follow-on activities from 2000 to 2010. These funds supported the Colombian Army's push into southern Colombia in support of the Colombian National Police, enhanced drug interdiction in Colombia and the region, increased support to the Colombian National Police, provided for economic development in Colombia and the Andean region, and boosted Colombia's local and national government capacity. Beginning in 2010, Andean Counterdrug Programs funds are appropriated in the International Narcotics Control and Law Enforcement account.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Implementing Partner Sub-category ID: Universities and Research Institutes - United States
Funding Account Name: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Activity Name: AmericasBarometer
Activity Description: Vanderbilt University conducts AmericasBarometer democracy, governance and citizen security surveys in Latin America and Caribbean countries and related country and regional analyses. Country reports and, when requested, oversampling reports can be prepared that compare results from areas with USAID-programs to the rest of the country. The biennial survey includes 40,000 survey across 25 countries in the hemisphere. Vanderbilt is also conducting an impact evaluation of the Agencys crime prevention activities under the Central America Regional Security Initiative (CARSI) in Guatemala, El Salvador and Panama.

Managing Agency Name: Department of Health and Human Services
Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
US Sector Name: Pandemic Influenza and Other Emerging Threats (PIOET)
Funding Account Name: Centers for Disease Control, Disease Control, Research, and Training
Funding Agency Name: Department of Health and Human Services
Activity Name: Global Measles Immunization Initiatives through PAHO.
Activity Description: Global Measles Immunization Initiatives through PAHO. The Measles Initiative, launched in 2001, is a partnership committed to reducing measles deaths    globally, with the goal of cutting measles deaths by 90 percent by 2010 compared with estimates from 2000.    Through the Initiative, CDC provides technical assistance to host governments to help plan, implement, and    evaluate immunization programs, including operations research, and provides funds to purchase bundled measles    vaccine for mass vaccination campaigns.

Activity Name: Anti-Trafficking in Persons Project [through Centro de Operaciones Anti-Contrabando(COAC)]

Activity Name: Technical Assistance for Financial Enforcement
Activity Description: Technical Assistance Programs provide long-term, resident advisors or short-term, intermittent advisors. Financial Enforcement Program advisors support government officials in the development of legal foundations, policies, and anti-corruption entities to: combat money laundering, terrorist financing and other financial crimes; confront organized crime and corruption; reorganize law enforcement and financial entities in developing economies to help them prevent, detect, investigate, and prosecute complex international financial crimes.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Democracy, Conflict and Humanitarian Assistance
Implementing Partner Sub-category ID: Universities and Research Institutes - Non United States
Funding Account Name: Economic Support Fund
Activity Name: Social Services
Activity Description: Assist special populations which may be vulnerable or at-risk on a temporary or chronic basis whose needs are not addressed under emergency humanitarian assistance or other programs. These include groups such as the disabled; orphans, children and at-risk youth; victims of trafficking; victims of gender-based violence; refugees, returnees, ethnic minorities, internally displaced or other socially excluded groups; the elderly; and female heads of household. Depending on circumstances, services may intend to protect groups; mitigate adverse conditions they face, or to remove barriers to help integrate them into society. Components may include measures to increase the capacity of local service and advocacy NGOs and/or professional social workers; to establish public/private service delivery partnerships as well as family and community focused service models; to establish effective referral networks; to develop appropriate service protocols and methods for screening prospective recipients; or to improve public understanding and sensitivity to the needs of the vulnerable. While services provided should not exclude victims of trafficking in persons, programs designed specifically for this group fall under the Peace and Security Objective under the Transnational Crime Area and the Trafficking in Persons and Migrant Smuggling Element.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: not applicable
Implementing Partner Name: Yanapuma Foundation (Fundacin para la Vida Sostenible Yanapuma)
Funding Account Name: Inter-American Foundation
Activity Name: Training in organization leadership to improve living standards through the development of sustainable agriculture, reforestation and environmental protection of the Tsa'chila of Bua.
Activity Description: Yanapuma Foundation (YANAPUMA), $29,740 over twelve months YANAPUMA will work in the indigenous Tsa'chila community of Bua to improve nutrition and income by cultivating organic cacao, fruit and vegetables using methods compatible with the responsible use of the environment. Training will emphasize the revival of a tree species and reforestation to decrease erosion and the contamination of local rivers. (EC-416)

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Funding Account Name: Economic Support Fund
Activity Name: Private Sector Productivity
Activity Description: Improve the capacity of businesses to integrate into domestic and international markets through increases in productivity and improvements in corporate governance and the development and application of modern technology and marketing practices. Enhance the capacity of businesses and business associations in terms of their corporate governance capabilities and their application of best practices and technologies to achieve increased production and marketing of products and services. It includes adoption of efficient production processes, improved labor productivity, environmentally-sound management of natural resources and the development of accounting and management systems that can help the company and industry group implement business, labor, product and process standards that enhance business competitiveness. Business capacity development programs may include activities that help men- and women-owned firms and associations respond to these international markets and create regional alliances.

Managing Sub-agency or Bureau Name: Bureau for Latin America and Caribbean
Funding Account Name: Economic Support Fund
Activity Name: Civic Participation
Activity Description: Strengthen the legal, regulatory, institutional, and information environment which protects and enables the growth in associational life and the development of independent and sustainable civil society organizations (CSOs).  Build the capacity of civil society organizations to act as agents for reform and support their participation in democratic decision-making through articulating and representing their members interests, engaging in service delivery, and advocating for issues which become part of the public agenda and are reflected in public policies. Encourage the strengthening of a civic culture which supports democratic institutions and processes, active participation in political and civic life, and the civic virtues of tolerance, pluralism, compromise, trust, and respect for individual rights, including gender equality.
